column2: A LITTLE TALK TO MY READERS.

column2: With The Sea Fairies, my book for 1911, I ventured into a new field of fairy literature and to my delight the book was received with much approval by my former readers,
column3: With The Sea Fairies, my book for nineteen eleven, I ventured into a new field of fairy literature and to my delight the book was received with much approval by my former readers,

column2: As Polychrome, the Rainbow's Daughter, lives in the sky, it is natural that Trot and Button-Bright meet her during their adventures there.
column3: As Polychrome, the Rainbow's Daughter, lives in the sky, it is natural that Trot and Button-Bright meet her during their adventures there.

column2: This story of Sky Island has astonished me considerably, and I think it will also astonish you. The sky country is certainly a remarkable fair land,
column3: This story of Sky Island has astonished me considerably, and I think it will also astonish you. The sky country is certainly a remarkable fair land,

column2: but after reading about it I am sure you will agree with me that our old Mother Earth is a very good place to live upon and that Trot and Button-Bright and captain Bill were fortunate to get back to it again.
column3: but after reading about it I am sure you will agree with me that our old Mother Earth is a very good place to live upon and that Trot and Button-Bright and captain Bill were fortunate to get back to it again.

column2: By the way, one of my little correspondents has suggested that I print my address in this book, so that the children may know where letters will reach me.
column3: By the way, one of my little correspondents has suggested that I print my address in this book, so that the children may know where letters will reach me.

column2: I am doing this, as you see, and hope that many will write to me and tell me how they like Sky Island. My greatest treasures are these letters from my readers and I am always delighted to receive them.
column3: I am doing this, as you see, and hope that many will write to me and tell me how they like Sky Island. My greatest treasures are these letters from my readers and I am always delighted to receive them.

column3: 'Father was away at the office, so I found it in the attic and I jus' took it.' Then Uncle Bob shook his head and said I ought to leave it alone.

column2: He said it was a fam'ly relic that had been handed down from father to son for many generations. But I told him my father had never handed it to me, though I'm his son.
column3: He said it was a fam'ly relic that had been handed down from father to son for many generations. But I told him my father had never handed it to me, though I'm his son.

column3: Where do you s'pose the real Sky Island can be? asked Trot presently.

column2: We can't tell anything about it until we get there, Button-Bright answered. Seems to me I've heard of the Isle of Skye, but that's over in Great Britain,
column3: We can't tell anything about it until we get there, Button-Bright answered. Seems to me I've heard of the Isle of Skye, but that's over in Great Britain,

column2: somewhere the other side of the world, and it isn't Sky Island, anyhow.
column3: somewhere the other side of the world, and it isn't Sky Island, anyhow.

column2: This miser'ble ol' umbrel is too pertic'ler, growled captain Bill. It won't let you change your mind and it goes ezzac'ly where you say.
column3: This miser'ble ol' umbrel is too pertic'ler, growled captain Bill. It won't let you change your mind and it goes ezzac'ly where you say.

column2: If it didn't, said Trot, we'd never know where we were going. We don't know now, said the sailor. One thing's certain, folks:

column2: we're gett'n' a long way from home. And see how the clouds are rolling just above us, remarked the boy, who was almost as uneasy as captain Bill.
column3: we're gett'n' a long way from home. And see how the clouds are rolling just above us, remarked the boy, who was almost as uneasy as captain Bill.

column2: We're in the sky, all right, said the girl. If there could be an island up here among the clouds, I'd think it was there we're going.
column3: We're in the sky, all right, said the girl. If there could be an island up here among the clouds, I'd think it was there we're going.

column2: Couldn't there be one? asked Button-Bright. Why couldn't there be an island in the sky that would be named Sky Island? Of course not! declared captain Bill.
column3: Couldn't there be one? asked Button-Bright. Why couldn't there be an island in the sky that would be named Sky Island? Of course not! declared captain Bill.

column2: There wouldn't be anything to hold it up, you know. What's holding US up? asked Trot.
column3: There wouldn't be anything to hold it up, you know. What's holding US up? asked Trot.

column2: Magic, I guess. Then magic might hold an island in the sky. Whee-e-e! What a black cloud! It grew suddenly dark, for they were rushing through a thick cloud that rolled around them in billows.
column3: Magic, I guess. Then magic might hold an island in the sky. Whee-e-e! What a black cloud! It grew suddenly dark, for they were rushing through a thick cloud that rolled around them in billows.

column2: Trot felt little drops of moisture striking her face and knew her clothing was getting damp and soggy.
column3: Trot felt little drops of moisture striking her face and knew her clothing was getting damp and soggy.

column2: It's a rain cloud, she said to Button-Bright, and it seems like an awful big one, because it takes so long for us to pass through it.
column3: It's a rain cloud, she said to Button-Bright, and it seems like an awful big one, because it takes so long for us to pass through it.

column2: The umbrella never hesitated a moment. It made a path through the length of the heavy, black cloud at last and carried its passengers into a misty,

column2: billowy bank of white, which seemed as soft and fleecy as a lady's veil.
column3: billowy bank of white, which seemed as soft and fleecy as a lady's veil.

column2: When this broke away, they caught sight of a majestic rainbow spanning the heavens, its gorgeous colors glinting brightly in the sun, its arch perfect and unbroken from end to end.
column3: When this broke away, they caught sight of a majestic rainbow spanning the heavens, its gorgeous colors glinting brightly in the sun, its arch perfect and unbroken from end to end.

column2: But it was only a glimpse they had, for quickly they dove into another bank of clouds and the rainbow disappeared.
column3: But it was only a glimpse they had, for quickly they dove into another bank of clouds and the rainbow disappeared.

column2: Here the clouds were not black, nor heavy, but they assumed queer shapes. Some were like huge ships, some like forest trees, and others piled themselves into semblances of turreted castles and wonderful palaces.
column3: Here the clouds were not black, nor heavy, but they assumed queer shapes. Some were like huge ships, some like forest trees, and others piled themselves into semblances of turreted castles and wonderful palaces.

column2: The shapes shifted here and there continually, and the voyagers began to be bewildered by the phantoms.
column3: The shapes shifted here and there continually, and the voyagers began to be bewildered by the phantoms.

column2: Seems to me we're goin' down, called Trot.
column3: Seems to me we're goin' down, called Trot.

column3: Down where? asked captain Bill.

column3: Is it an island? asked Trot solemnly.

column3: Suddenly, the basket that was dangling below captain Bill struck something with a loud thud, and this was followed by a yell of anger.

column3: There were many handsomely carved benches and seats of blue wood scattered about the garden, and near them stood a fountain made of blue marble,

column2: which shot lovely sprays of blue water into the blue air.
column3: which shot lovely sprays of blue water into the blue air.

column2: But the angry inhabitants of this blue place would not permit them to look around them in peace, for as soon as captain Bill rolled off his toes,
column3: But the angry inhabitants of this blue place would not permit them to look around them in peace, for as soon as captain Bill rolled off his toes,

column2: he began dancing around in an excited way and saying very disrespectful things of his visitors.
column3: he began dancing around in an excited way and saying very disrespectful things of his visitors.

column2: You brutes! You apes! You miserable, white-skinned creatures! How dare you come into my garden and knock me on the head with that awful basket and then fall on my toes and cause me pain and suffering?
column3: You brutes! You apes! You miserable, white-skinned creatures! How dare you come into my garden and knock me on the head with that awful basket and then fall on my toes and cause me pain and suffering?

column2: How dare you, I say? Don't you know you will be punished for your impudence? Don't you know the Boolooroo of the Blues will have revenge? I can have you patched for this insult,
column3: How dare you, I say? Don't you know you will be punished for your impudence? Don't you know the Boolooroo of the Blues will have revenge? I can have you patched for this insult,

column2: and I will just as sure as I'm the Royal Boolooroo of Sky Island!
column3: and I will just as sure as I'm the Royal Boolooroo of Sky Island!

column2: Oh, is this Sky Island, then? asked Trot.
column3: Oh, is this Sky Island, then? asked Trot.

column2: Of course it's Sky Island. What else could it be? And I'm its Ruler, its King, its sole Royal Potentate and Dictator. Behold in the Personage you have injured the Mighty Quitey Righty Boolooroo of the Blues!
column3: Of course it's Sky Island. What else could it be? And I'm its Ruler, its King, its sole Royal Potentate and Dictator. Behold in the Personage you have injured the Mighty Quitey Righty Boolooroo of the Blues!

column2: Here he strutted around in a very pompous manner and wagged his little head contemptuously at them.
column3: Here he strutted around in a very pompous manner and wagged his little head contemptuously at them.

column2: Glad to meet you, sir, said captain Bill. I allus had a likin' for kings, bein' as they're summat unusual. Please 'scuse me for a-sittin' on your royal toes,
column3: Glad to meet you, sir, said captain Bill. I allus had a likin' for kings, bein' as they're summat unusual. Please 'scuse me for a-sittin' on your royal toes,

column2: not knowin' as your toes were there.
column3: not knowin' as your toes were there.

column2: I won't excuse you! roared the Boolooroo. But I'll punish you. You may depend upon that. Seems to me, said Trot, you're actin' rather imperlite to strangers.
column3: I won't excuse you! roared the Boolooroo. But I'll punish you. You may depend upon that. Seems to me, said Trot, you're actin' rather imperlite to strangers.

column2: If anyone comes to our country to visit us, we always treat 'em decent. YOUR country! exclaimed the Boolooroo, looking at them more carefully and seeming interested in their appearance.
column3: If anyone comes to our country to visit us, we always treat 'em decent. YOUR country! exclaimed the Boolooroo, looking at them more carefully and seeming interested in their appearance.

column2: Where in the Sky did you come from, then, and where is your country located? We live on the Earth when we're at home, replied the girl.
column3: Where in the Sky did you come from, then, and where is your country located? We live on the Earth when we're at home, replied the girl.

column2: The Earth? Nonsense! I've heard of the Earth, my child, but it isn't inhabited. No one can live there because it's just a round, cold, barren ball of mud and water, declared the Blueskin.
column3: The Earth? Nonsense! I've heard of the Earth, my child, but it isn't inhabited. No one can live there because it's just a round, cold, barren ball of mud and water, declared the Blueskin.

column2: Oh, you're wrong about that, said Button-Bright.
column3: Oh, you're wrong about that, said Button-Bright.

column3: You surely are, added captain Bill.

column2: Why, we live there ourselves, cried Trot.
column3: Why, we live there ourselves, cried Trot.

column2: I don't believe it. I believe you are living in Sky Island, where you have no right to be, with your horrid white skins. And you've intruded into the private garden of the palace of the Greatly Stately Irately Boolooroo,
column3: I don't believe it. I believe you are living in Sky Island, where you have no right to be, with your horrid white skins. And you've intruded into the private garden of the palace of the Greatly Stately Irately Boolooroo,

column2: which is a criminal offense.
column3: which is a criminal offense.

column2: And you've bumped my head with your basket and smashed my toes with your boards and bodies, which is a crime unparalleled in all the history of Sky Island!
column3: And you've bumped my head with your basket and smashed my toes with your boards and bodies, which is a crime unparalleled in all the history of Sky Island!

column2: Aren't you sorry for yourselves? I'm sorry for you, replied Trot, because you don't seem to know the proper way to treat visitors.
column3: Aren't you sorry for yourselves? I'm sorry for you, replied Trot, because you don't seem to know the proper way to treat visitors.

column2: But we won't stay long. We'll go home pretty soon. Not until you have been punished! exclaimed the Boolooroo sternly.
column3: But we won't stay long. We'll go home pretty soon. Not until you have been punished! exclaimed the Boolooroo sternly.

column2: You are my prisoners. Beg parding, your Majesty, said captain Bill, but you're takin' a good deal for granted. We've tried to be friendly and peaceable,
column3: You are my prisoners. Beg parding, your Majesty, said captain Bill, but you're takin' a good deal for granted. We've tried to be friendly and peaceable,

column2: and we've 'poligized for hurtin' you, but if that don't satisfy you, you'll have to make the most of it.
column3: and we've 'poligized for hurtin' you, but if that don't satisfy you, you'll have to make the most of it.

column3: You may be the Boolooroo of the Blues, but you ain't even a tin whistle to us, and you can't skeer us for half a minute. I'm an ol' man, myself,

column2: but if you don't behave, I'll spank you like I would a baby, and it won't be any trouble at all to do it, thank'e.
column3: but if you don't behave, I'll spank you like I would a baby, and it won't be any trouble at all to do it, thank'e.

column3: As a matter of fact, we've captured your whole bloomin' blue island, but we don't like the place very much, and I guess we'll give it back.

column3: It gives us the blues, don't it, Trot? So as soon as we eat a bite of lunch from our basket, we'll sail away again. Sail away? How? asked the Boolooroo.

column2: I told you to let things alone, growled captain Bill. If you don't behave, your Majesty, this Blue Island'll have to get another Boolooroo. Why? asked the Blueskin.
column3: I told you to let things alone, growled captain Bill. If you don't behave, your Majesty, this Blue Island'll have to get another Boolooroo. Why? asked the Blueskin.

column2: Because I'll prob'ly spoil you for a king, and mebbe for anything else. Anyhow, you'll get badly damaged if you try to interfere with us, and that's a fact.

column2: Don't kill him, captain Bill, said Trot cheerfully.

column3: Kill me? Why, he couldn't do that, observed the King, who was trying to rearrange the ruffle around his neck. Nothing can kill me. Why not? asked captain Bill.

column2: Because I haven't lived my six hundred years yet. Perhaps you don't know that every Blueskin in Sky Island lives exactly six hundred years from the time he is born.

column2: It's a fact, said the King. Nothing can kill us until we've lived to the last day of our appointed lives. When the final minute is up, we die;
column3: It's a fact, said the King. Nothing can kill us until we've lived to the last day of our appointed lives. When the final minute is up, we die;

column2: but we're obliged to live all of the six hundred years whether we want to or not.
column3: but we're obliged to live all of the six hundred years whether we want to or not.

column2: So you needn't think of trying to kill anybody on Sky Island. It can't be done. Never mind, said captain Bill. I'm no murderer, thank goodness,
column3: So you needn't think of trying to kill anybody on Sky Island. It can't be done. Never mind, said captain Bill. I'm no murderer, thank goodness,

column2: and I wouldn't kill you if I could, much as you deserve it.
column3: and I wouldn't kill you if I could, much as you deserve it.

column2: But isn't six hundred years an awful long time to live? questioned Trot.
column3: But isn't six hundred years an awful long time to live? questioned Trot.

column2: It seems like it at first, replied the King, but I notice that whenever any of my subjects get near the end of their six hundred, they grow nervous and say the life is altogether too short.
column3: It seems like it at first, replied the King, but I notice that whenever any of my subjects get near the end of their six hundred, they grow nervous and say the life is altogether too short.

column2: How long have you lived? asked Button-Bright.
column3: How long have you lived? asked Button-Bright.

column2: The King coughed again and turned a bit bluer. That is considered an impertinent question in Sky Island, he answered, but I will say that every Boolooroo is elected to reign three hundred years,
column3: The King coughed again and turned a bit bluer. That is considered an impertinent question in Sky Island, he answered, but I will say that every Boolooroo is elected to reign three hundred years,

column2: and I've reigned not quite ahem! two hundred.
column3: and I've reigned not quite ahem! two hundred.

column2: Are your kings elected, then? asked captain Bill.
column3: Are your kings elected, then? asked captain Bill.

column2: Yes, of course. This is a Republic, you know. The people elect all their officers from the King down. Every man and every woman is a voter.
column3: Yes, of course. This is a Republic, you know. The people elect all their officers from the King down. Every man and every woman is a voter.

column2: The Boolooroo tells them whom to vote for, and if they don't obey, they are severely punished. It's a fine system of government, and the only thing I object to is electing the Boolooroo for only three hundred years.
column3: The Boolooroo tells them whom to vote for, and if they don't obey, they are severely punished. It's a fine system of government, and the only thing I object to is electing the Boolooroo for only three hundred years.

column2: It ought to be for life. My successor has already been elected, but he can't reign for a hundred years to come. I think three hundred years is plenty long enough, said Trot.
column3: It ought to be for life. My successor has already been elected, but he can't reign for a hundred years to come. I think three hundred years is plenty long enough, said Trot.

column2: It gives someone else a chance to rule, and I wouldn't be s'prised if the next king is a better one. Seems to me you're not much of a Boolooroo.
column3: It gives someone else a chance to rule, and I wouldn't be s'prised if the next king is a better one. Seems to me you're not much of a Boolooroo.

column2: That, replied the King indignantly, is a matter of opinion. I like myself very much, but I can't expect you to like me, because you're deformed and ignorant. I'm not! cried Trot.
column3: That, replied the King indignantly, is a matter of opinion. I like myself very much, but I can't expect you to like me, because you're deformed and ignorant. I'm not! cried Trot.

column2: Yes, you are. Your legs are too short and your neck is nothing at all.
column3: Yes, you are. Your legs are too short and your neck is nothing at all.

column2: Your color is most peculiar, but there isn't a shade of blue about any of you, except the deep-blue color of the clothes the old ape that choked me wears.
column3: Your color is most peculiar, but there isn't a shade of blue about any of you, except the deep-blue color of the clothes the old ape that choked me wears.

column2: Also, you are ignorant because you know nothing of Sky Island, which is the Center of the Universe and the only place anyone would care to live.
column3: Also, you are ignorant because you know nothing of Sky Island, which is the Center of the Universe and the only place anyone would care to live.

column2: one eye was half shut and twinkling, while the other was big and staring; his nose was thin on one side and flat on the other, while one side of his mouth curled up and the other down.
column3: one eye was half shut and twinkling, while the other was big and staring; his nose was thin on one side and flat on the other, while one side of his mouth curled up and the other down.

column2: Don't stare at him, a voice whispered in the boy's ear. The poor fellow has been patched, that's all. Button-Bright turned to see who had spoken and found by his side a tall young Blueskin with a blue-gold chain around his neck.
column3: Don't stare at him, a voice whispered in the boy's ear. The poor fellow has been patched, that's all. Button-Bright turned to see who had spoken and found by his side a tall young Blueskin with a blue-gold chain around his neck.

column2: He was quite the best looking person the boy had seen in Sky Island, and he spoke in a pleasant way and seemed quite friendly.
column3: He was quite the best looking person the boy had seen in Sky Island, and he spoke in a pleasant way and seemed quite friendly.

column2: But the two-sided man had overheard the remark, and he now stepped forward and said in a careless tone:
column3: But the two-sided man had overheard the remark, and he now stepped forward and said in a careless tone:

column2: Never mind. It's no disgrace to be patched in a country ruled by such a cruel Boolooroo as we have. Let the boy look at me if he wants to.
column3: Never mind. It's no disgrace to be patched in a country ruled by such a cruel Boolooroo as we have. Let the boy look at me if he wants to.

column2: I'm not pretty, but that's not my fault. Blame the Boolooroo. I I'm glad to meet you, sir, stammered Button-Bright. What is your name, please?
column3: I'm not pretty, but that's not my fault. Blame the Boolooroo. I I'm glad to meet you, sir, stammered Button-Bright. What is your name, please?

column2: I'm now named Jimfred Jonesjinks, and my partner is called Fredjim Jinksjones.
column3: I'm now named Jimfred Jonesjinks, and my partner is called Fredjim Jinksjones.

column2: He's busy at present guarding the Treasure Chamber, but I'll introduce you to him when he comes back. We've had the misfortune to be patched, you know.
column3: He's busy at present guarding the Treasure Chamber, but I'll introduce you to him when he comes back. We've had the misfortune to be patched, you know.

column2: What is being patched? asked the boy.
column3: What is being patched? asked the boy.

column2: They cut two of us in halves and mismatch the halves half of one to half of the other, you know and then the other two halves are patched together.
column3: They cut two of us in halves and mismatch the halves half of one to half of the other, you know and then the other two halves are patched together.

column2: It destroys our individuality and makes us complex creatures, so it's the worst punishment than can be inflicted in Sky Island.
column3: It destroys our individuality and makes us complex creatures, so it's the worst punishment than can be inflicted in Sky Island.

column2: Oh, said Button-Bright, alarmed at such dreadful butchery. Doesn't it hurt? No, it doesn't hurt, replied Jimfred. But it makes one frightfully nervous.
column3: Oh, said Button-Bright, alarmed at such dreadful butchery. Doesn't it hurt? No, it doesn't hurt, replied Jimfred. But it makes one frightfully nervous.

column2: They stand you under a big knife, which drops and slices you neatly in two, exactly in the middle. Then they match half of you to another person who has likewise been sliced,
column3: They stand you under a big knife, which drops and slices you neatly in two, exactly in the middle. Then they match half of you to another person who has likewise been sliced,

column2: and there you are, patched to someone you don't care about and haven't much interest in.
column3: and there you are, patched to someone you don't care about and haven't much interest in.

column2: If your half wants to do something, the other half is likely to want to do something different, and the funny part of it is you don't quite know which is your half and which is the other half.
column3: If your half wants to do something, the other half is likely to want to do something different, and the funny part of it is you don't quite know which is your half and which is the other half.

column2: It's a terrible punishment, and in a country where one can't die or be killed until he has lived his six hundred years, to be patched is a great misfortune.
column3: It's a terrible punishment, and in a country where one can't die or be killed until he has lived his six hundred years, to be patched is a great misfortune.

column2: I'm sure it is, said Button-Bright earnestly. But can't you ever get get UNpatched again? If the Boolooroo would consent, I think it could be done,
column3: I'm sure it is, said Button-Bright earnestly. But can't you ever get get UNpatched again? If the Boolooroo would consent, I think it could be done,

column2: Jimfred replied, but he never will consent.
column3: Jimfred replied, but he never will consent.

column2: This is about the meanest Boolooroo who ever ruled this land, and he was the first to invent patching people as a punishment.
column3: This is about the meanest Boolooroo who ever ruled this land, and he was the first to invent patching people as a punishment.

column2: I think we will all be glad when his three hundred years of rule are ended. When will that be? inquired the boy.
column3: I think we will all be glad when his three hundred years of rule are ended. When will that be? inquired the boy.

column2: Hush-sh-sh! cried everyone in a chorus, and they all looked over their shoulders as if frightened by the question. The officer with the blue-gold chain pulled Button-Bright's sleeve and whispered, Follow me, please.
column3: Hush-sh-sh! cried everyone in a chorus, and they all looked over their shoulders as if frightened by the question. The officer with the blue-gold chain pulled Button-Bright's sleeve and whispered, Follow me, please.

column2: And then he beckoned to captain Bill and led the two slaves to another room where they were alone.
column3: And then he beckoned to captain Bill and led the two slaves to another room where they were alone.

column2: I must instruct you in your duties, said he when they were all comfortably seated in cozy chairs with blue cushions. You must learn how to obey the Boolooroo's commands,
column3: I must instruct you in your duties, said he when they were all comfortably seated in cozy chairs with blue cushions. You must learn how to obey the Boolooroo's commands,

column2: so he won't become angry and have you patched.
column3: so he won't become angry and have you patched.

column2: How could he patch US? asked the sailorman curiously.
column3: How could he patch US? asked the sailorman curiously.

column2: Oh, he'd just slice you all in halves and then patch half of the boy to half of the girl, and the other half to half of you, and the other half of you to the other half of the girl.
column3: Oh, he'd just slice you all in halves and then patch half of the boy to half of the girl, and the other half to half of you, and the other half of you to the other half of the girl.

column2: See? Can't say I do, said captain Bill, much bewildered. It's a reg'lar mix-up. That's what it's meant to be, explained the young officer.
column3: See? Can't say I do, said captain Bill, much bewildered. It's a reg'lar mix-up. That's what it's meant to be, explained the young officer.

column2: and seein' as we're Earth folks, and not natives of Sky Island, I've an idea the slicing machine would about end us, without bein' patched, continued the sailor.
column3: and seein' as we're Earth folks, and not natives of Sky Island, I've an idea the slicing machine would about end us, without bein' patched, continued the sailor.

column2: Oh, said Button-Bright, so it would. While you are in this country, you can't die till you've lived six hundred years, declared the officer.
column3: Oh, said Button-Bright, so it would. While you are in this country, you can't die till you've lived six hundred years, declared the officer.

column2: Oh, said Button-Bright. That's different, of course. But who are you, please? My name is Ghip-Ghi-siz-zle. Can you remember it? I can 'member the 'sizzle,
column3: Oh, said Button-Bright. That's different, of course. But who are you, please? My name is Ghip-Ghi-siz-zle. Can you remember it? I can 'member the 'sizzle,

column2: ' said the boy, but I'm 'fraid the Gwip Grip Glip Ghip-Ghi-siz-zle repeated the officer slowly.
column3: ' said the boy, but I'm 'fraid the Gwip Grip Glip Ghip-Ghi-siz-zle repeated the officer slowly.

column2: I want you to remember my name, because if you are going to live here, you are sure to hear of me a great many times. Can you keep a secret? I can try, said Button-Bright.
column3: I want you to remember my name, because if you are going to live here, you are sure to hear of me a great many times. Can you keep a secret? I can try, said Button-Bright.

column2: I've kep' secrets once in a while, asserted captain Bill.
column3: I've kep' secrets once in a while, asserted captain Bill.

column2: Well, try to keep this one. I'm to be the next Boolooroo of Sky Island. Good for you! cried the sailor. I wish you was the Boolooroo now, sir.
column3: Well, try to keep this one. I'm to be the next Boolooroo of Sky Island. Good for you! cried the sailor. I wish you was the Boolooroo now, sir.

column2: But it seems you've got to wait a hundred years or more afore you can take his place. Ghip-Ghisizzle rose to his feet and paced up and down the room for a time, a frown upon his face.
column3: But it seems you've got to wait a hundred years or more afore you can take his place. Ghip-Ghisizzle rose to his feet and paced up and down the room for a time, a frown upon his face.

column2: Then he halted and faced captain Bill.
column3: Then he halted and faced captain Bill.

column2: Sir, said he, there lies all my trouble. I'm quite sure the present Boolooroo has reigned three hundred years next Thursday, but he claims it is only two hundred years,
column3: Sir, said he, there lies all my trouble. I'm quite sure the present Boolooroo has reigned three hundred years next Thursday, but he claims it is only two hundred years,

column2: and as he holds the Royal Book of Records under lock and key in the Royal Treasury, there is no way for us to prove he is wrong.
column3: and as he holds the Royal Book of Records under lock and key in the Royal Treasury, there is no way for us to prove he is wrong.

column2: Oh, said Button-Bright. How old is the Boolooroo? He was two hundred years old when he was elected, replied Ghip-Ghisizzle.
column3: Oh, said Button-Bright. How old is the Boolooroo? He was two hundred years old when he was elected, replied Ghip-Ghisizzle.

column2: If he has already reigned three hundred years as I suspect, then he is now five hundred years old. You see, he is trying to steal another hundred years of rule so as to remain a tyrant all his life.
column3: If he has already reigned three hundred years as I suspect, then he is now five hundred years old. You see, he is trying to steal another hundred years of rule so as to remain a tyrant all his life.

column2: He don't seem as old as that, observed captain Bill thoughtfully. Why, I'm only sixty myself, and I guess I look twice as old as your king does.
column3: He don't seem as old as that, observed captain Bill thoughtfully. Why, I'm only sixty myself, and I guess I look twice as old as your king does.

column2: We do not show our age in looks, the officer answered. I am just about your age, sir sixty-two my next birthday but I'm sure I don't look as old as that.
column3: We do not show our age in looks, the officer answered. I am just about your age, sir sixty-two my next birthday but I'm sure I don't look as old as that.

column2: That's a fact, agreed captain Bill. Then he turned to Button-Bright and added, Don't that prove Sky Island is a fairy country as I said? Oh, I've known that all along, said the boy.
column3: That's a fact, agreed captain Bill. Then he turned to Button-Bright and added, Don't that prove Sky Island is a fairy country as I said? Oh, I've known that all along, said the boy.

column2: The slicing and patching proves it, and so do lots of other things. Now then, said Ghip-Ghisizzle, let us talk over your duties.
column3: The slicing and patching proves it, and so do lots of other things. Now then, said Ghip-Ghisizzle, let us talk over your duties.

column2: It seems you must mix the royal nectar, captain Bill. Do you know how to do that? I'm free to say as I don't, friend Sizzle.
column3: It seems you must mix the royal nectar, captain Bill. Do you know how to do that? I'm free to say as I don't, friend Sizzle.

column2: The Boolooroo is very particular about his nectar. I think he has given you this job so he can find fault with you and have you punished.
column3: The Boolooroo is very particular about his nectar. I think he has given you this job so he can find fault with you and have you punished.

column2: But we will fool him. You are strangers here, and I don't want you imposed upon. I'll send Tiggle to the royal pantry and keep him there to mix the nectar.
column3: But we will fool him. You are strangers here, and I don't want you imposed upon. I'll send Tiggle to the royal pantry and keep him there to mix the nectar.

column2: Then when the Boolooroo or the Queen or any of the Snubnosed Princesses call for a drink, you can carry it to them and it will be sure to suit them.
column3: Then when the Boolooroo or the Queen or any of the Snubnosed Princesses call for a drink, you can carry it to them and it will be sure to suit them.

column2: Thank'e sir, said captain Bill. That's real kind of you. Your job, Button-Bright, is easier, continued Ghip-Ghisizzle.
column3: Thank'e sir, said captain Bill. That's real kind of you. Your job, Button-Bright, is easier, continued Ghip-Ghisizzle.

column2: I'm no bootblack, declared the boy. The Boolooroo has no right to make me do his dirty work. You're a slave, the officer reminded him, and a slave must obey. Why? asked Button-Bright.
column3: I'm no bootblack, declared the boy. The Boolooroo has no right to make me do his dirty work. You're a slave, the officer reminded him, and a slave must obey. Why? asked Button-Bright.

column2: Because he can't help himself. No slave ever wants to obey, but he just has to. And it isn't dirty work at all. You don't black the royal boots and shoes,
column3: Because he can't help himself. No slave ever wants to obey, but he just has to. And it isn't dirty work at all. You don't black the royal boots and shoes,

column2: you merely blue them with a finely perfumed blue paste.
column3: you merely blue them with a finely perfumed blue paste.

column2: Then you shine them neatly and your task is done. You will not be humiliated by becoming a bootblack. You'll be a bootblue.
column3: Then you shine them neatly and your task is done. You will not be humiliated by becoming a bootblack. You'll be a bootblue.

column2: Oh, said Button-Bright. I don't see much difference, but perhaps it's a little more respectable. Yes, the Royal Bootblue is considered a high official in Sky Island.
column3: Oh, said Button-Bright. I don't see much difference, but perhaps it's a little more respectable. Yes, the Royal Bootblue is considered a high official in Sky Island.

column2: You do your work at evening or early morning, and the rest of the day you are at liberty to do as you please. It won't last long, Button-Bright, said captain Bill consolingly.
column3: You do your work at evening or early morning, and the rest of the day you are at liberty to do as you please. It won't last long, Button-Bright, said captain Bill consolingly.

column2: Somethin's bound to happen pretty soon, you know. I think so myself, answered the boy.
column3: Somethin's bound to happen pretty soon, you know. I think so myself, answered the boy.

column2: And now, remarked Ghip-Ghisizzle, since you understand your new duties, perhaps you'd like to walk out with me and see the Blue City and the glorious Blue Country of Sky Island.
column3: And now, remarked Ghip-Ghisizzle, since you understand your new duties, perhaps you'd like to walk out with me and see the Blue City and the glorious Blue Country of Sky Island.

column2: We would that! cried captain Bill promptly.
column3: We would that! cried captain Bill promptly.

column2: So they accompanied their new friend through a maze of passages for the palace was very big and then through a high, arched portal into the streets of the City.
column3: So they accompanied their new friend through a maze of passages for the palace was very big and then through a high, arched portal into the streets of the City.

column2: So rapid had been their descent when the umbrella landed them in the royal garden that they had not even caught a glimpse of the Blue City, so now they gazed with wonder and interest at the splendid sights that met their eyes.
column3: So rapid had been their descent when the umbrella landed them in the royal garden that they had not even caught a glimpse of the Blue City, so now they gazed with wonder and interest at the splendid sights that met their eyes.

column2: Sky island by L Frank Baum. Chapter 8 THE BLUE CITY. The Blue City was quite extensive, and consisted of many broad streets paved with blue marble and lined with splendid buildings of the same beautiful material.
column3: Sky island by L Frank Baum. Chapter eight THE BLUE CITY. The Blue City was quite extensive, and consisted of many broad streets paved with blue marble and lined with splendid buildings of the same beautiful material.

column2: There were houses and castles and shops for the merchants, and all were prettily designed and had many slender spires and imposing turrets that rose far into the blue air.
column3: There were houses and castles and shops for the merchants, and all were prettily designed and had many slender spires and imposing turrets that rose far into the blue air.

column2: Everything was blue here, just as was everything in the Royal Palace and gardens, and a blue haze overhung all the city.
column3: Everything was blue here, just as was everything in the Royal Palace and gardens, and a blue haze overhung all the city.

column2: Doesn't the sun ever shine? asked captain Bill.
column3: Doesn't the sun ever shine? asked captain Bill.

column2: Not in the blue part of Sky Island, replied Ghip-Ghisizzle. The moon shines here every night, but we never see the sun.
column3: Not in the blue part of Sky Island, replied Ghip-Ghisizzle. The moon shines here every night, but we never see the sun.

column2: I am told, however, that on the other half of the Island which I have never seen the sun shines brightly but there is no moon at all.
column3: I am told, however, that on the other half of the Island which I have never seen the sun shines brightly but there is no moon at all.

column2: Oh, said Button-Bright. Is there another half to Sky Island?' Yes, a dreadful place called the Pink Country. I'm told everything there is pink instead of blue.
column3: Oh, said Button-Bright. Is there another half to Sky Island?' Yes, a dreadful place called the Pink Country. I'm told everything there is pink instead of blue.

column2: A fearful place it must be, indeed! said the Blueskin with a shudder.
column3: A fearful place it must be, indeed! said the Blueskin with a shudder.

column2: I dunno 'bout that, remarked captain Bill. That Pink Country sounds kind of cheerful to me. Is your Blue Country very big? It is immense, was the proud reply.
column3: I dunno 'bout that, remarked captain Bill. That Pink Country sounds kind of cheerful to me. Is your Blue Country very big? It is immense, was the proud reply.

column2: This enormous city extends a half mile in all directions from the center, and the country outside the City is fully a half-mile further in extent.
column3: This enormous city extends a half mile in all directions from the center, and the country outside the City is fully a half-mile further in extent.

column2: That's very big, isn't it? Not very, replied captain Bill with a smile. We've cities on the Earth ten times bigger, and then some big besides.
column3: That's very big, isn't it? Not very, replied captain Bill with a smile. We've cities on the Earth ten times bigger, and then some big besides.

column2: We'd call this a small town in our country. Our Country is thousands of miles wide and thousands of miles long it's the great United States of America! added the boy earnestly.
column3: We'd call this a small town in our country. Our Country is thousands of miles wide and thousands of miles long it's the great United States of America! added the boy earnestly.

column2: Ghip-Ghisizzle seemed astonished. He was silent a moment, and then he said, Here in Sky Island we prize truthfulness very highly.
column3: Ghip-Ghisizzle seemed astonished. He was silent a moment, and then he said, Here in Sky Island we prize truthfulness very highly.

column2: Our Boolooroo is not very truthful, I admit, for he is trying to misrepresent the length of his reign, but our people as a rule speak only the truth.
column3: Our Boolooroo is not very truthful, I admit, for he is trying to misrepresent the length of his reign, but our people as a rule speak only the truth.

column2: So do we, asserted captain Bill. What Button-Bright said is the honest truth, every word of it. But we have been led to believe that Sky Island is the greatest country in the universe meaning,
column3: So do we, asserted captain Bill. What Button-Bright said is the honest truth, every word of it. But we have been led to believe that Sky Island is the greatest country in the universe meaning,

column2: of course, our half of it, the Blue Country.
column3: of course, our half of it, the Blue Country.

column2: It may be for you, perhaps, the sailor stated politely. and I don't imagine any island floatin' in the sky is any bigger.
column3: It may be for you, perhaps, the sailor stated politely. and I don't imagine any island floatin' in the sky is any bigger.

column2: But the Universe is a big place, and you can't be sure of what's in it till you've traveled like we have. Perhaps you are right, mused the Blueskin,
column3: But the Universe is a big place, and you can't be sure of what's in it till you've traveled like we have. Perhaps you are right, mused the Blueskin,

column3: but he still seemed to doubt them.

column2: Is the Pink side of Sky Island bigger than the Blue side? asked Button-Bright.
column3: Is the Pink side of Sky Island bigger than the Blue side? asked Button-Bright.

column2: No, it is supposed to be the same size, was the reply.
column3: No, it is supposed to be the same size, was the reply.

column2: Then why haven't you ever been there? Seems to me you could walk across the whole island in an hour, said the boy.
column3: Then why haven't you ever been there? Seems to me you could walk across the whole island in an hour, said the boy.

column2: The two parts are separated by an impassable barrier, answered Ghip-Ghisizzle. Between them lies the Great Fog Bank. A fog bank? Why, that's no barrier! exclaimed captain Bill.
column3: The two parts are separated by an impassable barrier, answered Ghip-Ghisizzle. Between them lies the Great Fog Bank. A fog bank? Why, that's no barrier! exclaimed captain Bill.

column2: It is indeed, returned the Blueskin. The Fog Bank is so thick and heavy that it blinds one, and if once you got into the Bank, you might wander forever and not find your way out again.
column3: It is indeed, returned the Blueskin. The Fog Bank is so thick and heavy that it blinds one, and if once you got into the Bank, you might wander forever and not find your way out again.

column2: Also, it is full of dampness that wets your clothes and your hair until you become miserable.
column3: Also, it is full of dampness that wets your clothes and your hair until you become miserable.

column2: It is furthermore said that those who enter the Fog Bank forfeit the six hundred years allowed them to live and are liable to die at any time.
column3: It is furthermore said that those who enter the Fog Bank forfeit the six hundred years allowed them to live and are liable to die at any time.

column2: Here we do not die, you know; we merely pass away. How's that? asked the sailor. Isn't 'pass'n' away' jus' the same as dyin'? No indeed.
column3: Here we do not die, you know; we merely pass away. How's that? asked the sailor. Isn't 'pass'n' away' jus' the same as dyin'? No indeed.

column2: When our six hundred years are ended, we march into the Great Blue Grotto, through the Arch of Phinis, and are never seen again.
column3: When our six hundred years are ended, we march into the Great Blue Grotto, through the Arch of Phinis, and are never seen again.

column2: That's queer, said Button-Bright. What would happen if you didn't march through the Arch? I do not know, for no one has ever refused to do so.
column3: That's queer, said Button-Bright. What would happen if you didn't march through the Arch? I do not know, for no one has ever refused to do so.

column2: It is the Law, and we all obey it. It saves funeral expenses, anyhow, remarked captain Bill. Where is this Arch? Just outside the gates of the City.
column3: It is the Law, and we all obey it. It saves funeral expenses, anyhow, remarked captain Bill. Where is this Arch? Just outside the gates of the City.

column2: There is a mountain in the center of the Blue land, and the entrance to the Great Blue Grotto is at the foot of the mountain.
column3: There is a mountain in the center of the Blue land, and the entrance to the Great Blue Grotto is at the foot of the mountain.

column2: According to our figures, the Boolooroo ought to march into this Grotto a hundred years from next Thursday, but he is trying to steal a hundred years and so perhaps he won't enter the Arch of Phinis.
column3: According to our figures, the Boolooroo ought to march into this Grotto a hundred years from next Thursday, but he is trying to steal a hundred years and so perhaps he won't enter the Arch of Phinis.

column2: Therefore, if you will please be patient for about a hundred years, you will discover what happens to one who breaks the Law.
column3: Therefore, if you will please be patient for about a hundred years, you will discover what happens to one who breaks the Law.

column2: Thank'e, remarked captain Bill. I don't expect to be very curious a hundred years from now. Nor I, added Button-Bright, laughing at the whimsical speech.
column3: Thank'e, remarked captain Bill. I don't expect to be very curious a hundred years from now. Nor I, added Button-Bright, laughing at the whimsical speech.

column2: But I don't see how the Boolooroo is able to fool you all. Can't any of you remember two or three hundred years back when he first began to rule?
column3: But I don't see how the Boolooroo is able to fool you all. Can't any of you remember two or three hundred years back when he first began to rule?

column2: No, said Ghip-Ghisizzle, that's a long time to remember, and we Blueskins try to forget all we can, especially whatever is unpleasant.
column3: No, said Ghip-Ghisizzle, that's a long time to remember, and we Blueskins try to forget all we can, especially whatever is unpleasant.

column2: Those who remember are usually the unhappy ones; only those able to forget find the most joy in life. During this conversation they had been walking along the streets of the Blue City,
column3: Those who remember are usually the unhappy ones; only those able to forget find the most joy in life. During this conversation they had been walking along the streets of the Blue City,

column2: where many of the Blueskin inhabitants stopped to gaze wonderingly at the sailor and the boy, whose strange appearance surprised them.
column3: where many of the Blueskin inhabitants stopped to gaze wonderingly at the sailor and the boy, whose strange appearance surprised them.

column2: They were a nervous, restless people, and their egg-shaped heads, set on the ends of long, thin necks, seemed so grotesque to the strangers that they could scarcely forbear laughing at them.
column3: They were a nervous, restless people, and their egg-shaped heads, set on the ends of long, thin necks, seemed so grotesque to the strangers that they could scarcely forbear laughing at them.

column2: The bodies of these people were short and round and their legs exceptionally long, so when a Blueskin walked, he covered twice as much ground at one step as captain Bill or Button-Bright did.
column3: The bodies of these people were short and round and their legs exceptionally long, so when a Blueskin walked, he covered twice as much ground at one step as captain Bill or Button-Bright did.

column2: The women seemed just as repellent as the men, and Button-Bright began to understand that the Six Snubnosed Princesses were, after all,
column3: The women seemed just as repellent as the men, and Button-Bright began to understand that the Six Snubnosed Princesses were, after all,

column2: rather better looking than most of the females of the Blue Country and so had a certain right to be proud and haughty.
column3: rather better looking than most of the females of the Blue Country and so had a certain right to be proud and haughty.

column2: There were no horses nor cows in this land, but there were plenty of blue goats, from which the people got their milk.
column3: There were no horses nor cows in this land, but there were plenty of blue goats, from which the people got their milk.

column2: Children tended the goats wee Blueskin boys and girls whose appearance was so comical that Button-Bright laughed whenever he saw one of them.
column3: Children tended the goats wee Blueskin boys and girls whose appearance was so comical that Button-Bright laughed whenever he saw one of them.

column2: Although the natives had never seen before this any human beings made as Button-Bright and captain Bill were, they took a strong dislike to the strangers and several times threatened to attack them.
column3: Although the natives had never seen before this any human beings made as Button-Bright and captain Bill were, they took a strong dislike to the strangers and several times threatened to attack them.

column2: Perhaps if Ghip-Ghisizzle, who was their favorite, had not been present, they would have mobbed our friends with vicious ill-will and might have seriously injured them.
column3: Perhaps if Ghip-Ghisizzle, who was their favorite, had not been present, they would have mobbed our friends with vicious ill-will and might have seriously injured them.

column2: But Ghip-Ghisizzle's friendly protection made them hold aloof.
column3: But Ghip-Ghisizzle's friendly protection made them hold aloof.

column2: By and by they passed through a City gate, and their guide showed them the outer walls, which protected the City from the country beyond.
column3: By and by they passed through a City gate, and their guide showed them the outer walls, which protected the City from the country beyond.

column2: There were several of these gates, and from their recesses stone steps led to the top of the wall. They mounted a flight of these steps and from their elevation plainly saw the low mountain where the Arch of Phinis was located,
column3: There were several of these gates, and from their recesses stone steps led to the top of the wall. They mounted a flight of these steps and from their elevation plainly saw the low mountain where the Arch of Phinis was located,

column2: and beyond that the thick, blue-gray Fog Bank, which constantly rolled like billows of the ocean and really seemed, from a distance, quite forbidding.
column3: and beyond that the thick, blue-gray Fog Bank, which constantly rolled like billows of the ocean and really seemed, from a distance, quite forbidding.

column2: But it wouldn't take long to get there, decided Button-Bright, and if you were close up, it might not be worse than any other fog.
column3: But it wouldn't take long to get there, decided Button-Bright, and if you were close up, it might not be worse than any other fog.

column2: Is the Pink Country on the other side of it? So we are told in the Book of Records, replied Ghip-Ghisizzle. None of us now living know anything about it,
column3: Is the Pink Country on the other side of it? So we are told in the Book of Records, replied Ghip-Ghisizzle. None of us now living know anything about it,

column2: but the Book of Records calls it the 'Sunset Country' and says that at evening the pink shades are drowned by terrible colors of orange and crimson and golden-yellow and red.
column3: but the Book of Records calls it the 'Sunset Country' and says that at evening the pink shades are drowned by terrible colors of orange and crimson and golden-yellow and red.

column2: Wouldn't it be horrible to be obliged to look upon such a sight?
column3: Wouldn't it be horrible to be obliged to look upon such a sight?

column2: It must give the poor people who live there dreadful headaches. I'd like to see that Book of Records, mused captain Bill, who didn't think the description of the Sunset Country at all dreadful.
column3: It must give the poor people who live there dreadful headaches. I'd like to see that Book of Records, mused captain Bill, who didn't think the description of the Sunset Country at all dreadful.

column2: I'd like to see it myself, returned Ghip-Ghisizzle with a sigh, but no one can lay hands on it because the Boolooroo keeps it safely locked up in his Treasure Chamber.
column3: I'd like to see it myself, returned Ghip-Ghisizzle with a sigh, but no one can lay hands on it because the Boolooroo keeps it safely locked up in his Treasure Chamber.

column2: Where's the key to the Treasure Chamber? asked Button-Bright.
column3: Where's the key to the Treasure Chamber? asked Button-Bright.

column2: The Boolooroo keeps it in his pocket night and day, was the reply.
column3: The Boolooroo keeps it in his pocket night and day, was the reply.

column2: He is afraid to let anyone see the Book because it would prove he has already reigned three hundred years next Thursday, and then he would have to resign the throne to me and leave the Palace and live in a common house.
column3: He is afraid to let anyone see the Book because it would prove he has already reigned three hundred years next Thursday, and then he would have to resign the throne to me and leave the Palace and live in a common house.

column2: My Magic Umbrella is in that Treasure Chamber, said Button-Bright, and I'm going to try to get it. Are you? inquired Ghip-Ghisizzle eagerly.
column3: My Magic Umbrella is in that Treasure Chamber, said Button-Bright, and I'm going to try to get it. Are you? inquired Ghip-Ghisizzle eagerly.

column2: Well, if you manage to enter the Treasure Chamber, be sure to bring me the Book of Records. If you can do that, I will be the best and most grateful friend you ever had! I'll see, said the boy.
column3: Well, if you manage to enter the Treasure Chamber, be sure to bring me the Book of Records. If you can do that, I will be the best and most grateful friend you ever had! I'll see, said the boy.

column2: It ought not to be hard work to break into the Treasure chamber. Is it guarded? Yes. The outside guard is Jimfred Jinksjones, the double patch of the Fredjim whom you have met,
column3: It ought not to be hard work to break into the Treasure chamber. Is it guarded? Yes. The outside guard is Jimfred Jinksjones, the double patch of the Fredjim whom you have met,

column2: and the inside guard is a ravenous creature known as the Blue Wolf, which has teeth a foot long and as sharp as needles. Oh, said Button-Bright.
column3: and the inside guard is a ravenous creature known as the Blue Wolf, which has teeth a foot long and as sharp as needles. Oh, said Button-Bright.

column2: But never mind the Blue Wolf; I must manage to get my umbrella somehow or other. They now walked back to the palace, still objects of much curiosity to the natives,
column3: But never mind the Blue Wolf; I must manage to get my umbrella somehow or other. They now walked back to the palace, still objects of much curiosity to the natives,

column2: who sneered at them and mocked them but dared not interfere with their progress.
column3: who sneered at them and mocked them but dared not interfere with their progress.

column2: At the palace they found that dinner was about to be served in the big dining hall of the servants and dependents and household officers of the royal Boolooroo.
column3: At the palace they found that dinner was about to be served in the big dining hall of the servants and dependents and household officers of the royal Boolooroo.

column2: Ghip-Ghisizzle was the Majordomo and Master of Ceremonies, so he took his seat at the end of the long table and placed captain Bill on one side of him and Button-Bright on the other,
column3: Ghip-Ghisizzle was the Majordomo and Master of Ceremonies, so he took his seat at the end of the long table and placed captain Bill on one side of him and Button-Bright on the other,

column2: to the great annoyance of the other Blueskins present, who favored the strangers with nothing pleasanter than envious scowls.
column3: to the great annoyance of the other Blueskins present, who favored the strangers with nothing pleasanter than envious scowls.

column2: The Boolooroo and his Queen and daughters the Six Snubnosed Princesses dined in formal state in the Banquet Hall, where they were waited upon by favorite soldiers of the Royal Bodyguard.
column3: The Boolooroo and his Queen and daughters the Six Snubnosed Princesses dined in formal state in the Banquet Hall, where they were waited upon by favorite soldiers of the Royal Bodyguard.

column2: Here in the servants' hall there was one vacant seat next to Button-Bright which was reserved for Trot; but the little girl had not yet appeared,
column3: Here in the servants' hall there was one vacant seat next to Button-Bright which was reserved for Trot; but the little girl had not yet appeared,

column2: and the sailorman and the boy were beginning to be uneasy about her.
column3: and the sailorman and the boy were beginning to be uneasy about her.

column2: End of chapter 8.
column3: End of chapter eight.
